Stratify a data frame and apply a function

stratiply.Rd

Split a data.frame by any number of columns and apply a function to subset.

stratiply(
    data,
    f,
    by,
    ...
)

Arguments

data

A data.frame.
f

A function that takes a data.frame as an argument.
by

A vector of quoted/unquoted columns, positions, and/or tidyselect::select_helpers
...

Additional arguments passed to f.

Value

A list

Author

Alex Zajichek

Examples

#Unquoted selection
heart_disease %>%
    stratiply(
        head,
        Sex
    )

#> $Female
#> # A tibble: 6 x 8
#>     Age ChestPain         BP Cholesterol BloodSugar MaximumHR ExerciseInducedAn…
#>   <dbl> <fct>          <dbl>       <dbl> <lgl>          <dbl> <fct>             
#> 1    41 Atypical angi…   130         204 FALSE            172 No                
#> 2    62 Asymptomatic     140         268 FALSE            160 No                
#> 3    57 Asymptomatic     120         354 FALSE            163 Yes

#> 6    58 Typical angina   150         283 TRUE             162 No

#> # A tibble: 6 x 8
#>     Age ChestPain         BP Cholesterol BloodSugar MaximumHR ExerciseInducedAn…
#>   <dbl> <fct>          <dbl>       <dbl> <lgl>          <dbl> <fct>             
#> 1    63 Typical angina   145         233 TRUE             150 No                
#> 2    67 Asymptomatic     160         286 FALSE            108 Yes               
#> 3    67 Asymptomatic     120         229 FALSE            129 Yes               
#> 4    37 Non-anginal p…   130         250 FALSE            187 No

#> 6    63 Asymptomatic     130         254 FALSE            147 No

#Select helper
heart_disease %>%
    stratiply(
        f = head,
        by = starts_with("S")
    )

#> $Female
#> # A tibble: 6 x 8
#>     Age ChestPain         BP Cholesterol BloodSugar MaximumHR ExerciseInducedAn…
#>   <dbl> <fct>          <dbl>       <dbl> <lgl>          <dbl> <fct>             
#> 1    41 Atypical angi…   130         204 FALSE            172 No                
#> 2    62 Asymptomatic     140         268 FALSE            160 No                
#> 3    57 Asymptomatic     120         354 FALSE            163 Yes               
#> 4    56 Atypical angi…   140         294 FALSE            153 No                
#> 5    48 Non-anginal p…   130         275 FALSE            139 No                
#> 6    58 Typical angina   150         283 TRUE             162 No                
#> # … with 1 more variable: HeartDisease <fct>
#>

#> # A tibble: 6 x 8
#>     Age ChestPain         BP Cholesterol BloodSugar MaximumHR ExerciseInducedAn…
#>   <dbl> <fct>          <dbl>       <dbl> <lgl>          <dbl> <fct>             
#> 1    63 Typical angina   145         233 TRUE             150 No                
#> 2    67 Asymptomatic     160         286 FALSE            108 Yes               
#> 3    67 Asymptomatic     120         229 FALSE            129 Yes

#> 6    63 Asymptomatic     130         254 FALSE            147 No                
#> # … with 1 more variable: HeartDisease <fct>
#> 
    
#Use additional arguments for the function
heart_disease %>%
  stratiply(
        f = glm,
        by = Sex,
        formula = HeartDisease ~ .,
        family = "binomial"
  )

#> $Female
#> 
#> Call:  .f(formula = ..1, family = "binomial", data = .x[[i]])

#Use mixed selections to split by desired columns
heart_disease %>%
  stratiply(
        f = glm,
        by = c(Sex, is.logical),
        formula = HeartDisease ~ Age,
        family = "binomial"
  ) 

#> Warning: Predicate functions must be wrapped in `where()`.
#> 
#>   # Bad
#>   data %>% select(is.logical)
#> 
#>   # Good
#>   data %>% select(where(is.logical))
#>
